Author: mparris
Content:
My vote is AutoID, which is one of the oldest specs.

It makes use of Data Access, method calls, and subscriptions to Events. To get data, you can subscribe to a single tag, but for higher speed applications where timing matters, there is an event that a client can subscribe to, where the data is sent asynchronously, like MQTT. This overcomes the inherent latency with poll/response of subscribing to a tag with a fixed publish rate.

I know of three companies that sell products making use of this spec.

Author: mparris
Content: When working for GE Industrial Solutions, "digital thread" was defined as connecting the engineers desk to manufacturing as closely as possible. What an engineer designs in 3d CAD can go straight to the plant floor for execution. Remove the translation to paper drawings and reinterpretations along the way; have manufacturing consume what the engineer develops directly.

Author: mparris
Content: It was weird for me to hear "digital thread" used as a term by IT types to describe the direct connection from a sensor to some application in the cloud.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
It's not even clear that FactoryTalk Linx, when deployed on the 1756-CMS1B1 compute module, could even access the tags in the processor.  While the backplane is CIP messaging, the compute module exposes it as a DLL to Windows apps.  FactoryTalk Linx would need CIP transported with EtherNet/IP to expose the controller tags as an OPC-UA Server.

In other words, for a ControlLogix to have an "onboard" OPC-UA server, both the processor and compute module residing on the same backplane would each need to be plugged into an Ethernet switch to work together.

Author: brianpribe
Content: So you would need a custom API to access the tags right off the backplane (no controller middleware) and then send that out as OPC-UA to Azure.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
It has an API to access tags among other things over the backplane.  It does, however, require a custom host application to make use of the API.  Additionally, this custom application would need an OPC-UA Server interface implemented.

At that point, it would probably be easier to simply bypass OPC.  There isn't much benefit in converting extracted tag values from CIP messages pulled in over the backplane API to OPC-UA only to have it eventually converted again to Azure's internal JSON messaging.  It's abstracting a complicated interface into something even more complicated.  It would much more simple to use an Azure IoT Device library in the host application to publish the tag values as JSON payloads over AMQP, MQTT, or HTTPS.

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
If you phrased this as "any vendor that requires their own SDK to connect to a cloud MQTT broker", I'd mostly agree.    But you didn't, so I don't.

A robust IoT cloud platform is far more than just a broker.  And even if MQTT is the transport, layered SDKs that provide access to higher level services through that transport can be immensely helpful and valuable.   Heck, Cirrus Link's own MQTT libraries/modules for Ignition have layered SDKs for stuff like file transfers.

Simple stuff like the way the Azure IoT SDK makes device methods work is MASSIVELY valuable and goes beyond what you can do with SpB and an MQTT broker.

Layer on that a variety of device provisioning and onboarding capabilities that some of these SDKs and their corresponding platforms provide, and they can make it a WHOLE lot easier to connect and manage large numbers of devices vs a raw MQTT broker.

And I like cloud IoT platforms that also offer a REST API so that devices that don't want to open persistent connections can be easily implemented.

TL;DR : the world of IoT is more than what an MQTT broker providers.

And HiveMQ is the best MQTT broker.  ‚ô•Ô∏è

Author: trentc
Content:
As a technology addict since birth, and working controls for 2 decades....
This....This is the controls platform that I have been dreaming of. 
Honestly, I'm not sure why I'm just now discovering it and we aren't discussing ctrlX more.

It's open, extensible, secure, mostly web based, remotely managed, has API for nearly everything that you can do in the web interface. All of which are contrary to most current controls systems, and in alignment for our digital future.

It combines the freedom of programming languages, and many of the latest software features with realtime control.

And allowing a common "Data Layer" for all platform applications to access it's very own UNS!!!

With our younger generation focused on more modern technologies, capabilities and programming languages, I believe this approach can help draw more interest from this demographic. They will be able to solve more problems using technologies that meet their more modern expectations.

Considering the future of controls, with the only factor being technology, and if ctrlX delivers on what it promises....I don't know why I would choose any other platform for my machines.

Content:
I understand the difference between subscription and perpetual licenses. It's not always easy for us to step out of the subscription model and grow the product portfolio as a company.  We considered it many times.

Some of our customers have found a creative solution: they purchase a site license for Industrial DataOps, which grants them unlimited installations at that site. This allows them to deploy ‚Äúprotocol converter‚Äù instances (e.g., BACnet to OPC UA or Fanuc to OPC UA) as an added benefit at no additional cost. However, this means that the deployment didn‚Äôt originally focus on protocol conversion as a primary objective‚Äîit became an added bonus.
